questions.question: If the deadline for a school project changes, does your child reorganize their tasks to meet the new deadline?
When your child gets interrupted by phone notifications while studying for an exam, do they put it away and return to studying?
When asked about the strategies to improve concentration while playing a board game, does your child say that improving their interest in the game helped?
While helping you prepare a meal, if you run out of an ingredient, does your child suggest alternative ingredients or the complete the dish?
While completing a household chore, when your child is interrupted by a phone call, do they continue after answering it?
Does your child remain engaged while attending an online class even if there are background noises at home?
While playing board games, does your child say that they are being distracted by the constant talking of others?
If there is distraction when watching TV, does your child say that they will watch the program later or when no one is at home?
When playing a board game, does your child talk about improving attention by ignoring distractions and focusing on the game?
Does your child try to improve their attention to watch TV, either by increasing the volume to hear clearly or by focusing on the lip movements, etc.?
While watching TV, does your child say that a particular scene is boring or difficult to understand and hence their strategies to avoid distraction are not working?
If a planned outing gets canceled due to weather conditions, does your child quickly come up with alternative plans?
When planning to meet a friend, does your child adjust their plans if something unexpected comes up?
Does your child tell you about their plans to improve their attention while playing board games, such as they will request others to not talk or will play with a different set of people etc.?
When asked about lectures in school, does your child talk about whether their strategies to improve concentration have helped?
If your child has trouble solving a math problem, do they try different approaches to find the solution?
When asked about lectures in school, does your child talk about their plans to pay more attention?
If you call out to your child while they are working on an assignment, do they pause to help and then return to their work afterward?
Does your child efficiently complete chores despite background noise or conversations?
Have you noticed your child put their phones on silent to avoid social media notifications and instead focus on their studies?
Does your child talk about ways to improve their attention during lectures at school, such as sleeping on time, listening more carefully, etc.?

activities.name: Task Puzzle
activities.objective: Foster reflective thinking by analyzing which parts of a task demand more focus and arranging them accordingly.
activities.instructions: Explain to the child that they have to choose a task that has to be broken down into smaller task pieces like a puzzle (For example: cleaning their room, or working on a school project).##After they have written the sub-tasks down, ask them to think about which tasks seem like they will require more concentration or are trickier, and which tasks are interesting to the child.##Next, ask them to decide the order of the tasks based on its concentration or difficulty level.##Discuss why the child chose this order and how they factored in the difficulty and concentration level for the task.##Follow up with the child if they were able to complete the task, if they needed to adjust the plan, and whether this helped them plan for the task better.
activities.dos: Ensure the task chosen can be broken down into multiple sub-tasks.##Differentiate between tasks that need to be done in a specific order versus tasks that can be done in a chosen order. This is essential for the activity.
activities.donts: Do not push the child to create the order in a specific way, let them use their reasoning for the same.

indicator.name: Plans tasks according to their concentration level and interest

activities.name: Concentration Calendar
activities.objective: To help the child identify their best focus times and plan tasks effectively based on their concentration levels.
activities.instructions: Tell the child that they have to create a "Concentration Calendar". Ask them to create an hour log by listing down the hours of the day (For example, from 9 am-to 8 pm).##Next, ask them to think of when they are most energetic and focused during the day and break down the hours into high-concentration, and low concentration times. (For example, feeling most energetic in the morning and afternoon, least energetic in the late evening.) Ask them to color code or put symbols accordingly.##Now ask them to think of 2 tasks to be completed over the day and assign them in the best time slot based on the concentration levels and interest of the child.##Discuss whether this approach was effective in the next session.
activities.dos: Let the child choose their own tasks.##Encourage them to think about their real energy levels based on past experience.
activities.donts: Donâ€™t force them into a strict schedule, rather ask them to focus on energy levels over assigned hours. ##Do not skip the reflection and discussion of whether the activity was effective. Discuss how they would've planned differently after they tried.

indicator.name: Plans tasks according to their concentration level and interest

activities.name: Crack the Secret Message!
activities.objective: Strengthen focus and problem-solving by cracking an encrypted code under distraction.
activities.instructions: Ask the child to imagine they are secret agents who have intercepted an encrypted message. Their mission is to crack the code before time runs out!##Before starting, explain that they will face a distraction during the taskâ€”either a background audio (for example, people talking, music) or a visual distraction (for example, flashing colors on the screen). Their goal is to solve the puzzle and also identify the different distractions.##Provide the child with a coded worksheet (below) and the key to decipher it. While they work, introduce the audio or visual distraction. Cipher Key options: Each letter in the message has been shifted forward by 3 places in the alphabet (A â†’ D, B â†’ E, etc.). A = 1, B = 2, C = 3 â€¦ Z = 26 (Simple Number Code).##After the activity, discuss with the child all the distractions they were able to identify.
activities.dos: Encourage the child to break the code into smaller parts and work methodically. Let them pause and refocus if the distraction gets overwhelming.##Praise creative problem-solving and determination in cracking the code.##Ensure the child knows the activity is timed.
activities.donts: Donâ€™t overwhelm them with too many distractions at onceâ€”introduce them gradually.##Avoid rushing the decoding processâ€”accuracy is more important than speed.##Donâ€™t dismiss their own strategiesâ€”if they find a way to focus better, encourage it.

indicator.name: Tunes out environmental sounds while working

activities.name: Quiet Quest
activities.objective: Improve selective attention by maintaining focus on a task despite background sound distractions.
activities.instructions: Place a variety of objects on a table in front of the child.##Assign the child a focused task such as solving a puzzle or reading a book for a set period of time.##While they are engaged in the task, gradually introduce subtle sound distractions one at a timeâ€”for example, ringing a bell, playing soft music, or gently tossing a softball nearby.##After the task, talk with the child about which sounds they noticed and whether any were especially distracting.
activities.dos: Choose an age-appropriate task and introduce sound distractions slowly, one at a time.##Observe quietly and give positive feedback for sustained focus.
activities.donts: Avoid loud or sudden noises and multiple distractions happening at once.##Donâ€™t interrupt the child during the task; save questions for after.

indicator.name: Tunes out environmental sounds while working

activities.name: Distraction Dice
activities.objective: Develop strategies to manage different types of distractions.
activities.instructions: Explain to the child the concept of a distraction dice, where each number corresponds to a specific type of interruption (for example, 1: external noise, 2: internal thoughts, 3: emotional shift, 4: physical sensation, 5: peer distraction, 6: urgent interruption).##For each type of distraction, prepare a list of possible interruptions (for example, for emotional shift: â€œyou remember something embarrassingâ€).##Roll the dice and, based on the number that lands, read out the corresponding distraction prompt aloud.##Ask the child to think of two strategies for managing the interruption and write them down.##After the game, discuss which type of distraction might be the hardest to ignore and ask the child to try out some of the strategies in their daily tasks. Follow up in future sessions to check on the effectiveness of these strategies.
activities.dos: Ensure the types of distractions and prompts are relevant to the childâ€™s everyday experiences.##Encourage the child to think creatively and practically when developing strategies for each interruption.
activities.donts: Avoid using interruptions that are too complex or difficult for the child to relate to.##Donâ€™t rush through the discussion; allow the child enough time to reflect on the strategies.

indicator.name: Finds ways to manage interruptions and resume the task

activities.name: Focus Flip Cards
activities.objective: Develop awareness of different types of distractions and strategies to regain focus.
activities.instructions:
Create a set of cards that have common distraction scenarios (for instance, I am trying to study but there is construction noise outside, or I am doing chores but I keep thinking about playing my videogame.)##Explain to the child that you can have internal distractions, such as unhelpful thoughts, fidgeting, or lack of motivation, or external distractions such as noise, or interruptions. ##Ask the child to answer the following questions for each card:
*
Is this an external or internal distraction?
*
How does this affect my focus?
*
What can i do to flip back to focus?##The child can flip the card to write down their answers.
activities.dos: Use realistic and relatable distraction scenarios that the child might encounter daily.##Provide support and examples if the child struggles to identify distraction types or coping strategies.
activities.donts: Avoid overly complex or abstract distractions that may confuse the child.##Donâ€™t rush through the cards; allow the child time to reflect and articulate their answers.

indicator.name: Finds ways to manage interruptions and resume the task

activities.name: Project Reboot
activities.objective: Develop adaptability by planning and revising a project under changing conditions.
activities.instructions: Have the child create a detailed plan to complete a complex personal project (For example, a craft project, or a science experiment.)##This would involve planning the materials/resources, the steps to completing the project, the schedule of completion.##Introduce time restrictions or unexpected changes (For example, a crucial material is missing, or deadline has changed.)##Ask them to revise their plan based on existing resources.##Reflect on how they adjusted their schedule, what they prioritized, and why.
activities.dos: Encourage the child to break the project into clear, manageable steps.##Allow the child to choose a project they find interesting.##Praise creative solutions and flexible thinking during revisions.
activities.donts: Do not make the challenges unrealistic for their age or ability level.

indicator.name: Revises plan based on changing demands

activities.name: Flexi-Planner
activities.objective: Develop problem-solving skills by planning and adapting an event based on real-world challenges.
activities.instructions: Ask the child to plan an event detailing the activities, the schedule, the attendees, etc. (For example, a cultural fair, a holiday, or a talent show.)##Once they present a detailed plan, introduce real-world challenges (for instance, weather changes, lower attendance, or budget cuts.)##Have them revise their plan considering these issues.##Conclude by discussing how they made decisions based on priorities, resources, and logical thinking.
activities.dos: Offer prompts that encourage logical justification (For example, â€œWhy did you cut this part of the plan?â€).##Provide realistic changes in the plan.
activities.donts: Donâ€™t dismiss their creative solutions, even if unconventional.##Donâ€™t let the activity become purely logistical; focus on the why behind every change.

indicator.name: Revises plan based on changing demands
